etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in James Dana (1813–1895), geologist, zoologist, and teacher. From scientific Latin Titanotherium Titanotherium: see -there

definitions: Any of the very large extinct ungulates constituting the family Brontotheriidae from the Eocene of North America, resembling gigantic rhinoceroses with two bony horns side by side on the snout.
